results.title: [In the present]
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Originally part of a two-channel installation, this work presents a series of elusive narrative moments culled from snippets of ordinary life and oddly extraordinary objects. These moments gain their meaning on the periphery of perception. Writes Baldino: According to William James, the ‘present’ is about 3 to 12 seconds long; everything else is constructed memory. Each segment of In the Present is within this time frame. What you see or don’t see depends on what you remember. Your memory becomes part of the picture and distorts the idea of ‘present’ time.

Each segment of In the Present is within this time frame. What you see or don’t see depends on what you remember. Your memory becomes part of the picture and distorts the idea of ‘present’ time.

results.title: Galerie de portraits
results.creator_credit: Image Vidéo, Dominique Loreau and Marie André
results.brief_description: In ‘Galerie de portraits’, Marie Andre sketches the portraits of five women from among her closest friends and family (including her grandmother and daughter), composing an intimate, intensely private space. Her eloquent compositions focus on the quotidian, the richness inherent in such everyday gestures as watering a plant, lighting a cigarette, stirring a cup of tea. A ‘portrait’ of a woman is drawn from a corner of her room, the objects on her table, or the view onto which she gazes from a window. Andre, master of the subtle romance of the everyday, distils only what is essential — still life’s, nuances, spaces, the rhythm of voices — to obliquely portray the personal essence of the women and convey the intimacy between the artist and her female subjects.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 84]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

This film shows the ‘J. Gadsden Pty. Ltd.’ factory in North Coburg (now a heritage listed location) from early construction through to completion and operational. We see the production line during the manufacture of Coralite British Kerosene packaging and other unidentified products.

results.title: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Explains by use of close-up photography the threading, operation and care of the RCA 400 16 millimetre film and sound projector. Demonstrates the correct procedures for setting up and operating the equipment. Illustrates the packing up, cleaning and lubricating of the projector.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 166]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This is a particularly lovely colour film comprising scenes from Ron and Jess Gadsden’s early life when their children were small, in 1952. They are enjoying life at home (Lansell Rd, Toorak in Melbourne), sitting in the sun with the children, on the beach at Frankston on the Mornington Peninsula and a birthday for one of the girls back at Lansell Rd.

The second half of the film shows school sports at the Geelong Grammar Toorak Campus, ‘Glamorgan’, which Ron films through a round frame.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:59:00 Jess Gadsden teaches one of her children to swim in shallows at Frankston beach
00:01:59:00 view of Frankston bay with cliff top houses in the background
00:02:20:00 filmmaker Ron playing in water with his children
00:03:12:00 Jess preparing lunch on a small plate sitting on the beach
00:04:14:00 birthday party at Jess and Ron Gadsden’s home, with family and pony rides
00:06:42:00 sports day for primary school children with onlooking parents and teachers guiding the proceedings

results.title: [Nixon Family Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

In this film, the Nixon family are living in Alice Springs in 1966, until we see them returning to Victoria via a TAA flight. TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) was the major air service in the 1960s and 1970s flying to destinations all over Australian and its near neighbours of Papua New Guinea and Timor. One of the most memorable advertising jingles at the time was ‘Up, Up and away, with TAA, the Friendly, Friendly Way…’, a variation on the 1967 song Up, Up and Away, written by Jimmy Webb and also used by the US airline TWA.

At home in Herne Hill, new baby Stuart is introduced to the camera, in his ‘bassinette’, laughing at the camera, bouncing in a ‘bouncinette’, in his bath, in his ‘highchair’ and sitting on big sister Karen’s lap. The family spend time at the beach and Karen celebrates her fourth birthday.

Scenes of the Melbourne Zoo show the difference in standards for zoological practices between the 1960s and contemporary practices.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:23:00 view of houses in the arid setting of Alice Springs
00:01:15:00 mountain scenery seen across the scrubby desert
00:01:49:00 memorial for ‘Flynn of the Inland’
00:02:22:00 Dorothy wearing a very 1960s style ‘sunsuit’ for hot weather
00:02:30:00 children playing in a portable backyard swimming pool
00:03:16:00 views of rocks and a creek followed by Alice Springs township from a higher vantage point
00:04:50:00 (faint) carvings on a rock face
00:05:15:00 ‘John Flynn Church’
00:05:25:00 cars in Alice Springs
00:05:56:00 Karen wearing sunglasses
00:06:40:00 views around an Indigenous settlement
00:07:11:00 children eating watermelon
00:07:28:00 floods in the outback
00:07:45:00 TAA (Trans Australian Airlines) airplane on the tarmac at an outback airport
00:07:53:00 propeller of flying plane and views of the sea and land below, followed by landing scenes
00:08:51:00 scenes of baby Stuart at home in Herne Hill, Geelong
00:09:50:00 baby Stuart in a ‘bouncinette’ and in his ‘bassinette’
00:11:55:00 Les and Karen with baby Stuart
00:12:42:00 Dorothy in a Ford ‘Cortina’ model car
00:13:29:00 scenes at the beach
00:14:03:00 Karen and companion buried in the sand at the beach
00:15:48:00 scenes at the Melbourne Zoo
00:16:33:00 Karen’s fourth birthday celebrations
00:17:13:00 baby Stuart almost crawling across the carpet
00:18:08:00 Karen shows a popular activity of the time – the ‘hula hoop’
00:18:45:00 Stuart in a crate on the back of a bicycle
00:18:47:00 Karen shows off her ‘cowgirl’ outfit
00:19:17:00 baby Stuart walking
00:19:31:00 Karen and baby brother Stuart on a tricycle (trike)
00:21:00:00 baby Stuart walking with a toy lawn mower, on his tricycle and with Karen showing off a new outfit
00:21:37:00 at the beach and in the water
00:22:21:00 Dorothy and the children in new outfits in red and orange
00:23:06:00 late 1960s or early 1970s wedding
00:23:28:00 Les in 1970s style shorts and long socks
00:24:04:00 a ‘Victa’ brand lawn mower
00:25:30:00 garden scenes
00:25:40:00 a cricket game

In the Nixon Family Home Movie Collection, married film enthusiasts Les and Dorothy Nixon have captured their family life from when their children are very young to when they are young adults, at home in Geelong, during wonderful beach holidays at Point Roadknight on the Victorian coast, and when going about their everyday activities, from the 1960s to the 1980s.

The films show life in regional and suburban Victoria at the time: playing in the backyard and bike riding down the street (no helmets of course), lots of tennis, lots of beach and swimming, lots of family visits, birthday parties and family barbeques or picnic gatherings. Along the way, the films also record the distinctive fashion (often handmade) and hairstyles of the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s, through Dorothy Nixon being so stylish a dresser herself, and at the many family weddings across the extended family.

The films are made on Standard 8mm and then Super 8mm film, and are in reasonable condition though a little shaky or damaged at times.

In this film Les and Dorothy Nixon show off their first baby Karen (who features in the Nixon Collection until she is an adult herself) at their home in Herne Hill, Geelong, Victoria. There are also a few family weddings and visits and outings around Victoria.

These scenes are a lovely showcase of a baby’s first months, Karen’s first smiles, sitting up, being fed first ‘solids’, learning to crawl on the carpet, trying to open the kitchen cupboards and eventually walking. As well as these usual baby activities we see them in the context of the 1960s - style of clothes, carseat, bassinette, pram and playpen.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:25:00 infant Karen being carried around the family backyard by teenage girls, (possibly cousins in the large extended Corry-Nixon family)
00:01:02:00 family members climb a rock formation, followed by views of surrounding scenery
00:01:15:00 scenes of baby Karen’s christening or baptism day (assumed by the style of baby clothes and blanket and by Dorothy’s smart outfit which includes matching hat, gloves and necklace)
00:01:37:00 baby Karen being held by her grandmother and great aunt
00:01:47:00 baby Karen with father Len
00:02:19:00 baby Karen laughing in her bassinette
00:02:30:00 a family gathering for a beach picnic
00:04:11:00 extended family members gather for a photo with baby Karen
00:05:45:00 baby Karen being fed from a bowl, while she sits in her bassinette on the back porch of the home followed by a bath
00:06:54:00 a ‘dummy’ (pacifier or soother) hanging from above the bassinette
00:07:11:00 extended family members gather in front of one of their homes for a group scene; one of the women flits across the screen playfully swinging her skirt for the camera
00:08:00:00 baby Karen with Dorothy
00:08:57:00 a Holden model car from the era
00:10:20:00 baby Karen’s new car seat
00:11:21:00 an older baby Karen with a cousin in the backyard
00:12:09:00 a very 1960s style wedding
00:12:12:00 baby Karen chases an empty cigarette pack across the carpet floor, practising her crawling
00:13:57:00 baby Karen in her pram
00:14:46:00 Les mowing the lawn
00:15:08:00 first steps for Karen, with dad
00:15:30:00 at the beach, splashing around in the sea with cousins
00:16:25:00 family members paddle boarding and surfing
00:17:38:00 Karen wearing a sunbonnet in a ‘playpen’
00:18:46:00 Karen playing and laughing with dad
00:19:17:00 a lovely little rowboat named ‘Sea Wyf’
00:20:14:00 Karen crawling and first steps
00:21:40:00 Karen ‘frosting’ the window
00:21:56:00 a family picnic
00:24:01:00 women dressed in smart outfits including hats
00:24:09:00 1960s wedding in light blue
00:25:50:00 toddler Karen playing with bucket and spade at the beach
00:26:25:00 Karen and Les practise swimming with a board and family beach scenes
00:28:18:00 gladioli flowers in a vase, in the fashion of the day
00:30:43:00 public gardens

results.title: Timber
results.brief_description: A survey of the forests from which Australia obtains timber supplies for firewood, building and other industrial purposes. Illustrates tree-felling and the various methods used to transport logs to timber-mills. Overviews the preservation of natural forests and revegetation programs.

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Michaelis’s daughter, Sally Cohen, and her husband Sheldon Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film shows an amateur game fishing trip that appears to take place in Bermagui. We see images of the pier with people boarding the small boats and preparing for the fishing trip. Once they set sail, we see seals on the rocks and dolphins swimming alongside the boat. The fishing expedition is a great success. A 250lb marlin is caught and brought on board. The catch of the day is taken back to the pier and admired by impressed onlookers. It is weighed, hung from a wooden scaffold, and put on public display. The flank of the fish is tattooed with the name of the fisherman, (R. Michaels), the marlin’s weight and the date of the catch – 6 February 1938. Various locals stop by and pose with the fish to have their photos taken. In the background are vintage cars and a Shell petrol pump alongside a general store which offers hardware, motor accessories and fishing tackle.

This film shows fashion, cars, buildings and amateur fishing boats. It is a snapshot of game fishing and all that it entails in Bermagui.

Selected Highlights List (timecodes from Access Overscan)

00:01:00:00 fishing boats moored at a pier in what could be Bermagui; people board the boats in readiness for a fishing trip
00:08:00:00 people standing and walking along the pier; good details of the boats
00:25:00:00 two men organise equipment and provisions on the boat
00:48:00:00 a man is seen shooting film footage from a passing boat called Marlin
00:03:17:00 Orion passenger liner sails past the fishing boat
00:03:32:00 game fishing from boat, a marlin is hooked on the line and reeled in
00:03:43:00 fisherman reeling in the marlin
00:04:13:00 marlin is reeled in to the side of the boat and thrashes around in the water
00:04:24:00 the marlin is pulled on to the deck
00:05:33:00 the fishing boat arrives back at the pier
00:05:56:00 the marlin is winched onto the pier watched by onlookers
00:06:23:00 weighing the marlin on the pier
00:07:21:00 the marlin hangs from wooden hoist/scaffold showing handwritten sign on the flank of the marlin: 6/2/38 R. Michaelis 250lb Bermagui
00:07:44:00 a man stands and poses beside the hanging marlin
00:08:05:00 man stands beside hanging marlin in front of an old Shell petrol pump and Plume signage; General Hardware shop front advertising motor accessories and fishing tackle

results.title: [Orwell Michaelis Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Sheldon and Sally Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film depicts scenes of Bali and Java taken while on a holiday in 1939. The film is divided into sections indicated by titles: ‘Native Law Court –The Ceiling is Decorated with Pictures of Punishments’; ‘A Balinese Beauty’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – The Procession’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – at the Temple’; ‘Polishing Rice’; ‘Cockfighting is a Popular Past time’; ‘Java’; ‘Java – Selecta-A Hill station above Soerabaja’; ‘Java Semarang’; ‘The Borobudur’; ‘A Mohammedan Funeral at Djockjakarta’; ‘Buitenzorg – Government House and the Botanical Gardens’.

This film is interesting for the Balinese and Javanese street, local transport and people scenes. Images of the architecture, temples, cultural traditions and ceremonies are also a highlight. The film shows pottery techniques and a pottery ware market. There is footage of a funeral procession and a traditional Balinese temple festival or Odalan. The film shows elaborate offerings of fruit and food which is brought with great ceremony by the locals to the temple. We see Borobudur and surrounds, including details of the temple walls and structure. Dutch spelling and place names, as well as images of the hill station resort Selecta, reflect Indonesia’s colonial history and provide context for the time in which the film was made.

Selected Highlights List (timecodes from Access Overscan)

00:00:01:00 title: “Bali-Native Law Court– the Ceiling is Decorated with Pictures of Punishments”
00:00:16:00 images of the ceiling of what appears to be an outdoor law court depicting painted representations of Balinese punishments
00:00:40:00 women carrying baskets on their head walk down a palm-fringed dirt road
00:01:23:00 local woman works at a potter wheel making a bowl
00:01:46:00 local men walking down a road carrying a multitude of basket ware across their shoulders on their heads
00:01:54:00 pottery market
00:02:06:00 local woman tending to lotus flowers and garden; this is posed footage for the photographer and is titled “A Balinese Beauty”
00:02:32:00 title: “A temple birthday Festival – the procession” (or Odalan)
00:02:37:00 local people prepare for an Odalan procession
00:03:13:00 the procession of local women carry food and baskets and offerings on their head to the temple
00:03:55:00 tall elaborate offerings of fruit and food are carried in to temple
00:04:05:00 tall elaborate food offerings are carried on the heads of women descending the steps to the temple
00:04:14:00 black-and-white footage of elaborate food offerings being carried on the heads of women to the temple
00:05:29:00 colour footage of women carrying enormous baskets of produce on their heads
00:05:38:00 people polishing rice
00:06:27:00 a family and a dog walk down a rural road beside a rice paddy carrying baskets on their head
00:06:45:00 title: “Cockfighting is a popular past time”
00:06:46:00 cockfighting roosters in their baskets
00:07:00:00 cock owner shows off his rooster
00:07:09:00 old man and child with their cock
00:07:29:00 title: “Java Selecta – a Hill Station above Soerabaja” (Dutch spelling of Surabaya)
00:07:35:00 views from the Hill station look-out point
00:07:45:00 the manicured lawns of the Selecta resort with Dutch/Netherlands flag flying
00:07:57:00 scenes of the resort swimming pool and bathers
00:08:33:00 street scenes of Semarang showing bicycles, pedestrians, motor scooters, horses and carts, buildings and houses
00:08:50:00 buildings/houses with Chinese writing and balconies adorned with washing lines
00:09:01:00 school children on foot and bicycles travel along the road in front of what could be a school
00:09:17:00 colonial house perched on a hill in lush surroundings
00:09:23:00 Borobudur temple and surrounds, showing close-ups of temple details and statues
00:10:10:00 a group of children gather on the verandah of what could be a school
00:10:18:00 local women wash clothes in a river while children swim in the surrounding water
00:10:28:00 title: “A Mohammedan Funeral Procession at Djockjakarta” (Yogyakarta)
00:10:32:00 mourners attend a Muslin/Islamic funeral procession accompanying the coffin as it is carried along the street
00:10:48:00 bullocks and cart travel down a dirt road
00:10:53:00 title: “Buitenzorg – Government House and the Botanical Gardens”
00:10:59:00 Government House with pond and flamingos in the foreground

description_for_label:
This collection of home movies, originally filmed on 8mm and 16mm film, was taken between 1938 and 1956 by Orwell Michaelis. The collection was donated to ACMI by Sheldon and Sally Cohen. The films show life in Melbourne including the 1956 Olympic Games, a fishing trip to Bermagui in NSW, and holidays in Indonesia.

This film depicts scenes of Bali and Java taken while on a holiday in 1939. The film is divided into sections indicated by titles: ‘Native Law Court –The Ceiling is Decorated with Pictures of Punishments’; ‘A Balinese Beauty’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – The Procession’; ‘A Temple Birthday Festival – at the Temple’; ‘Polishing Rice’; ‘Cockfighting is a Popular Past time’; ‘Java’; ‘Java – Selecta-A Hill station above Soerabaja’; ‘Java Semarang’; ‘The Borobudur’; ‘A Mohammedan Funeral at Djockjakarta’; ‘Buitenzorg – Government House and the Botanical Gardens’.

This film is interesting for the Balinese and Javanese street, local transport and people scenes. Images of the architecture, temples, cultural traditions and ceremonies are also a highlight. The film shows pottery techniques and a pottery ware market. There is footage of a funeral procession and a traditional Balinese temple festival or Odalan. The film shows elaborate offerings of fruit and food which is brought with great ceremony by the locals to the temple. We see Borobudur and surrounds, including details of the temple walls and structure. Dutch spelling and place names, as well as images of the hill station resort Selecta, reflect Indonesia’s colonial history and provide context for the time in which the film was made.
